Dialog.text: Riley. Things on Talos I are becoming... untenable. It's time to set contingencies we've discussed into motion.
I need you to copy everything you've got onto the Vault Operator I sent you. The research. Connectomes. Everything.
Morgan was right. The Typhon are all linked. Which means whatever's happening up here will likely spread to you - if it hasn't already.
And it should go without saying that we keep the board out of the loop on this. They'll find out soon enough anyway.
Get it done.
We'll talk again soon.
Oh - and Riley - be careful. I'm fairly certain you've got at least one KASMA mole working for you.
Before you launch that operator I need you to take one last precaution.
You have the emulation tech Morgan was tinkering with. Use it. Copy yourself.
I know it seems morbid, but we can't shrink from the reality that you might not make it off the moon. This will ensure at least something is left of our family.
No one else is equipped to deal with what's coming.
I'm putting Talos I in the dark after this. You won't be able to reach me.
Hopefully, we'll see each other Earthside.
Goodbye, cousin.
This is Alex Yu, CEO of TranStar and co-director of research aboard Talos I.
When you look up, take pride and remember we are looking down on you with appreciation.

As I sit here, comfortably aboard the greatest technological marvel humanity has ever achieved, I recognize that this station wouldn't exist without the sustaining efforts of our sibling facility on the surface of the moon.
Our Helium 3 refinery alone is the lifeblood of this company, not to mention the exciting R&D taking place down there.
So, I want to offer my thanks and support to our employees hard at work at the Pytheas Moonbase.
Ah, yes. Officer Bhatia. Come in.
You have a son in the AIL, is that right?
You must be proud of him.
Maybe we can find a place for him on the TranStar Security team one day, hmm?
Straight to it. I like that about you, Vijay.
Here. What would you make of this?
No. I found it here. In my room.
No, Vijay. I don't suspect you. I wouldn't have called you in if I did.
But maybe... another member of your team? Perhaps acting on someone else's orders.
That's the problem, isn't it?
We imagine too little.
Picture what it would take for one of your men to betray you. How they would do it. Why. Imagine if you failed to detect them.
Then imagine my disappointment.
I'm sure you will. That's all, Officer Bhatia. You can leave that here with me.
